conclusion: Two sliders A and B with equal mass m are connected by a light rope and placed on an inclined plane at angle θ = 37°, with a horizontal force F applied to slider B. The system is on the verge of not sliding upwards, with μ = 0.5, sin(37°) = 0.6, and cos(37°) = 0.8.
The problem involves analyzing forces acting on the sliders to find the magnitude of the external force F.
The maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction, and gravitational acceleration is g.
The image shows two sliders A and B connected by a rope on an inclined plane at an angle of 37°, with a horizontal force F applied to slider B.
From sin²θ + cos²θ = 1, cos(37°) is calculated as 0.8.
Forces acting on slider A include weight (mg), normal force (NA), friction force (fA), and tension (T) in the rope.
Weight parallel to incline for slider A is mg·sin(37°) = 0.6mg.
Weight perpendicular to incline for slider A is mg·cos(37°) = 0.8mg.
Normal force for slider A is NA = 0.8mg.
Friction force for slider A is fA = μ·NA = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg.
Forces acting on slider B include weight (mg), normal force (NB), friction force (fB), horizontal force F, and tension (T') in the rope.
Weight parallel to incline for slider B is mg·sin(37°) = 0.6mg.
Weight perpendicular to incline for slider B is mg·cos(37°) = 0.8mg.
Normal force for slider B is NB = 0.8mg.
Friction force for slider B is fB = μ·NB = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg.
Force F has components: parallel to incline F·cos(37°) = 0.8F and perpendicular to incline F·sin(37°) = 0.6F.
The system is at equilibrium, with both sliders about to move upward if any additional force is applied.
For slider A, equilibrium along the incline gives T - 0.6mg - 0.4mg = 0, so T = 1.0mg.
